subject: Re: Help,what's wrong with my TDD practice in my daily life?
msgSnippet: ... I agree with you ,In fact I hadn t noticed it s a generalization . unnecessary logic introduces unnecessary risk (which is particularly higher given the
messageBody:
Jeff Langr wrote:
>
> Greetings Yang Gu,
>
> Hah! Fool me once. :-)
>
> I think your post is a good example of the importance of
> paying attention and asking questions. I certainly failed that
> test in this case! I remember a test I took in grade school:
>
> 1. read all instructions before proceeding
> 2. write down the names of the planets
> 3. etc.
> ...
> 25. ignore all preceding steps
>
> I hadn't even noticed that a number of kids had put their pencil
> down in the first 20 seconds. Yeah, sure, read instructions.
>
> The initial solution you provided presents more than a simple
> refactoring. It's a generalization, one that your requirement
> doesn't demand. I wouldn't have bothered with the refactoring
> in that case--the unnecessary logic introduces unnecessary risk
> (which is particularly higher given the absence of more
> comprehensive tests).

I agree with you ,In fact I hadn't noticed it's a generalization .
"unnecessary logic introduces unnecessary risk (which is
particularly higher given the absence of more comprehensive tests)"
it's great ,This is fact indeed.

I know the principle 'Do the simplest work' but I don't have a lot
of experience and lack of judgment on the principle.

Now with your help I noticed my mistake is that I did the
unnecessary work.This should be avoided in TDD practice.


In addtion,I am very sorry for my confused word and fool
ereryone,This isn't what I want.

Especially, Jeff ,I'm very sorry for fool you. :)

I'm very glad for your help,It's my pleasure ,thank everyone.

Best Regards
